item.title: Use flatpak!
item.description: Two days ago, I was attempting to install GNOME Fractal but apt-get couldn’t find it… Cause it’s a GNOME application I thought is was unexpected, so I checked the README file. It turned out that the developers actually suggest to install their app with either Snap or Flatpak. As I knew about the former and hadn’t heard about the later, I decided to install flatpak. 1 $ apt install flatpak I then used flatpak to install Fractal.

item.title: Installing Spell Right on VSCodium v1.49
item.description: VSCodium is an automatic “clean” build of Virtual Studio Code (VSCode), i.e. a build without the Microsoft touch. item.title: From one character encoding to another
item.description: Today I needed to check the character encoding of a file, I found this page that explains how to do this. Basically the command file will give you the info, for instance: 1 2 $ file example.md example.md: ASCII text options -i for --mime and -b for --brief will give: 1 2 $ file -bi example.md text/plain; charset=us-ascii I figured out that I needed to convert my file from one character encoding to another and so I used iconv.

item.title: How to count non-blank lines of a set of files?
item.description: Yesterday, I was trying to find a way to count lines of a set of R files without comments nor empty lines and found this answer on stackoverflow: 1 cat R/* | sed '/^\s*#/d;/^\s*$/d' | wc -l Exactly what I needed! A few explanations are in order: cat reads files sequentially; "|" is the the pipe operator; sed parses and transforms text; wc counts words, lines and more! Basically, counting lines of a file is done with the option -l of wc (option -m for characters, see man wc to learn more):
